conclusion: To determine how the shadows A, B, C, and D change when the light source moves backwards, we need to consider the principles of shadow formation and how they are affected by the position of the light source.

Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, casting a silhouette on a surface. The size and position of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface.
In the image, we have four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D. The light source is currently positioned such that these shadows are visible on the ground.

premise: As the light source moves backwards (away from the objects), the angle at which light hits the objects changes.
conclusion: This typically causes shadows to elongate and move further away from the objects.

premise: The further the light source is from the objects, the larger the shadows become.
conclusion: This is because the light rays are more parallel, causing the shadow to stretch.

premise: Shadow A will elongate and move further away from the object casting it.
conclusion: Its size will increase as the light source moves backwards.

premise: Shadow B will also elongate and increase in size, moving further from the object.
conclusion: Shadow B will elongate and increase in size, moving further from the object.

premise: Shadow C will experience the same elongation and size increase, moving further from the object casting it.
conclusion: Shadow C will elongate and increase in size, moving further from the object.

premise: Shadow D will elongate and increase in size, moving further from the object.
conclusion: Shadow D will elongate and increase in size, moving further from the object.

premise: As the light source moves backwards, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will elongate, increase in size, and move further away from their respective objects.
conclusion: The shadows will become larger and more stretched out on the ground.
